content.question: In Wisconsin v. Yoder (1972) how did the Supreme Court's decision address state interests and individual rights?

choices.label: It ruled that the state had an overarching right to compel students of all ages to attend public school through the twelfth grade.
It ruled that the state had no justifiable interest to compel students of all ages to attend public school through the twelfth grade.
It balanced the state’s interest in compulsory education with the students’ free speech rights.
It balanced the state’s interest in compulsory education with the students’ free exercise rights.

content.answer: It balanced the state’s interest in compulsory education with the students’ free exercise rights.
